See the treasures in the Smedley Museum

Wondering what it's like to be at Toastmasters International World Headquarters in the Ralph C. Smedley Museum? Now you can see it from every angle! Simply tilt your smart phone or tablet, or drag your mouse on your desktop to view this exciting 3D, 360 degree photo. 

Take a look at a few of Ralph C. Smedley’s favorite things including his original typewriter and desk, historical documents, photos and more.

By joining a Toastmasters International club, you can practice public speaking in a relaxed, safe environment. You'll get tips and constructive criticism from polished professionals and experts, helping you hone your skills and get more comfortable at the front of the room. http://bit.ly/2nJPQrQ

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Keith Hayden, CL
Hickam Toastmasters Club, Honolulu, Hawaii

A Look into Leadership

For officers in the United States Air Force, leadership is an everyday endeavor. Whether in the office or in a deployed environment in charge of a large unit (or just in charge of ourselves), we need leadership. Toastmasters has provided me with a professional and permissive environment, not only to hone my own leadership skills, but more importantly to help young Airmen develop theirs.

When I attend Toastmasters functions with other clubs in our district, I notice that most club members I meet are older professionals who want to improve their speaking and leadership skills. But my club is unique in two fundamental ways: 1) most of our members are under 30 and generally have little experience with public speaking, and 2) most of them are affiliated with the military, or are serving in the military, which means our membership is transitory. These two factors influence our club greatly, and as a result most meetings are focused on keeping a younger audience engaged while helping them develop as leaders and communicators.

I joined Toastmasters in June 2015, and because I believe strongly in the Toastmasters mission, I signed up for a leadership position during the second meeting I attended. Our club has been Distinguished for 10 years, thanks to very dedicated members who have since moved on in their careers. Our club’s success now rests on my shoulders and on those of my fellow officers.

Come and learn how to cultivate your interpersonal communication skills in a fun, friendly and professional environment!  Everyone can benefit both professionally and personally by improving their communication skills. Toastmasters is probably the best way to develop those skills quickly in a friendly environment.
Join us for light complimentary refreshments and meet our members!  

For more information contact:  Tom Loughlin, VP of Membership at 336-508-4420 or ETL704@yahoo.com. 

After you contact Tom to reserve your spot, head on over to www.toastmasters.org to learn more about Toastmasters! Toastmasters International -Home. Become the Leader and Speaker you want to be.

Lawyer from Singapore wins Toastmasters' 2016 World Championship of Public Speaking®

Darren Tay rises above 30,000 participants to win world's largest speech contest
With a humorous speech titled "Outsmart; Outlast," Darren Tay, a 27-year-old newly minted lawyer from Singapore, won the Toastmasters World Championship of Public Speaking on Saturday, Aug. 20.  Tay, along with nine other finalists, reached the championship level after several elimination rounds that began six months ago with 30,000 participants from more than 100 countries.

Teaching, leading with passion, compassion. After leaving his home in Vietnam with thousands of others who fled during the 1970s and ’80s after the war, ...

#Toastmasters, A new twist on table topics. Lessons are learned from impromptu speaking in members' native tongue. 
http://ow.ly/4n0g1x 

#publicspeaking #impromptu #diversity #leadership. A New Twist on Table Topics.

A Table Topics Workout. Check out these Table Topics survival tips for presenters and Table Topicsmasters in this Toastmaster magazine article.

Photo Credit: Katherine Hanneman of Hickam Toastmasters Club in #Honolulu #Hawaii
#PublicSpeaking #Communication #Leadership #TableTopics. Toastmasters International -Table Topics Workout. Decades later, Table Topics is still a signature club activity. While the purpose of encouraging participation remains the same, the benefits embrace much more. That simple one- to two-minute impromptu speech can transform your communication and leadership skills. Love it or loathe it, Table Topics….

Fuel Your Mental Engine.

Eat a light meal at least 20 minutes prior to your speech. For more #publicspeaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/SufBF #Toastmasters #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Embrace your unique style. 

Be yourself; no one does that better than you can. For more #publicspeaking and #communication tips, visit the #Toastmasters 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/PXleM #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Ask a thought-provoking question. 

Capture the audience’s attention by asking a question they may not know the answer to.  For more #publicspeaking and #communication tips, visit the 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/P6mRU #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Be Passionate.  

Find topics that mean a lot to you. If you are asked to speak to a topic that you don’t feel connected with, look for a connection that interests you. For more #publicspeaking and #communication tips, visit the 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/OKw58  #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Be the expert.

Make sure that you've researched your topic in depth prior to your speaking engagement. For more #publicspeaking and #communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page:  http://ow.ly/NcxEC #Toastmasters. Timeline Photos.

Trust Your Instincts

If your gut tells you to steer into another direction or bring up a certain topic, listen to what it says. For more #Toastmasters #publicspeaking and #communication tips, visit our #90Tips Page: http://ow.ly/MUrVz #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Seek Opportunities Everywhere.

Seek opportunities to practice your #communication skills, whether it’s sharing an idea at a work meeting or talking to people in public. For more #publicspeaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/Mvujo #Toastmasters. Timeline Photos.

Use humor when things go wrong. 

Tell a quick joke to help put you and your audience at ease. For more #publicspeaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/LFrIt #Toastmasters. Timeline Photos.

Fuel Your Mental Engine.

Eat a light meal at least 20 minutes prior to your speech.  For more #publicspeaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/L6e16 #Toastmasters #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

Why practice Table Topics? 

Table Topics is a long-standing #Toastmasters tradition and can help you prepare for these 10 weirdest job interview questions asked by real companies: http://ow.ly/KZn1J. Top 10 Weirdest Job Interview Questions in 2015. We know job seekers need to be prepared for anything but is it me, or are job interview questions just getting weirder and weirder?!

Push the envelope.

Take risks, but know your audience and don't present material simply for shock value.  Have a point and the facts to back it up. For more public speaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/KQXS2  #Toastmasters #publicspeaking. Timeline Photos.

Enjoy Yourself. 

When choosing a topic for your speech, find something that is important to you. Your commitment to the topic will help sell the speech to your audience. For more public speaking and communication tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/KyrN0 #Toastmasters. Timeline Photos.

Don't overload your slides.

This year marks our 90th anniversary so we have #90Tips from #Toastmasters. For more public speaking and leadership tips, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/KdbbC #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

It's time for some #Toastmasters trivia!

What was the name of the first two-page newsletter started in 1930? For more 90th anniversary trivia and table topics, go here: http://ow.ly/K7BM9 #TI90years. Timeline Photos.

PREP. Point. Reason. Example. Point.

This year is our 90th anniversary and we have #90Tips from #Toastmasters. For more 90th anniversary resources, go here: http://ow.ly/JYTiQ #TI90years. Timeline Photos.
Today marks my 25th anniversary in this wonderful organization.

Need to take a mid-day break?

Try out our 90th Anniversary #Toastmasters History Crossword Puzzle!  Let's see who can get them all correct! #TI90years http://ow.ly/GWSsW. Timeline Photos.

This year marks our 90th anniversary and we want to hear more from you! What is your personal history with Toastmasters? 

For this and more history themed trivia, visit our 90th anniversary page: http://ow.ly/G4DYa #TI90years #whereleadersaremade. Timeline Photos.

In honor of our 90th anniversary this year we want to know: If you had a chance to meet #Toastmasters' founder, Dr. Ralph C. Smedley, what would you say to him or ask him?  

For more history themed table topic questions visit our 90th Anniversary Page: http://ow.ly/Fn1Ux #TI90years #whereleadersaremade. Timeline Photos.

In honor of our 90th anniversary this year we want to know:
#Toastmasters clubs are present in 126 countries.  If you could visit any club, where would you go and why?

For more history themed table topic questions visit our 90th Anniversary Page:  http://ow.ly/EXbhO #TI90years #whereleadersaremade. Timeline Photos.

It’s time again for some #Toastmasters Trivia in honor of our 90th Anniversary! 

The question is… “When was the first annual Toastmistress Convention held?”
Everyone who answers correctly will be entered for a chance to win a FREE Toastmasters Keychain (Item 5997)! Comment here or email socialmedia@toastmasters.org with your answers by 5 PM PST. Good luck! #TI90Years #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

It’s time again for some #Toastmasters Trivia in honor of our 90th Anniversary! 

The question is… “What is Ralph Smedley's middle name?”
Everyone who answers correctly will be entered for a chance to win a FREE Toastmasters Keychain (Item 5997)! Comment here or email socialmedia@toastmasters.org with your answers by 5 PM PST. Good luck! #TI90Years #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

In honor of our 90th anniversary year, it’s time again for some Toastmasters Trivia! 

The question is… “Where did the second official club charter?”
Everyone who answers correctly will be entered for a chance to win a FREE Toastmasters Keychain (Item 5997)! Comment here or email socialmedia@toastmasters.org with your answer by 5 PM PST. Good luck! #TI90Years #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

Happy Anniversary Toastmasters!

Our 90th Anniversary is an important milestone in our organization’s history.  In honor of our 90th Anniversary today, we'd love to hear why you're a Toastmaster! Join our “90 Reasons to be a Toastmaster” event to share your stories, anecdotes and motives for joining Toastmasters. Submissions may be featured in upcoming publications, social media or on the website. To keep track of reasons from around the world, when you post, please use the hashtags #TI90Reasons and #TI90Years. 90 Reasons to be a Toastmaster. In honor of our 90th Anniversary today, we'd love to hear why you're a Toastmaster! Share your stories, anecdotes and  motives for joining Toastmasters. Submissions may be featured in upcoming publications, social media or on the website.  To keep track of reasons from around the world use our hashtags #TI90Reasons and #TI90years.

Toastmasters Turns 90 Next Week!
Let’s join together in celebrating this important milestone! Check out our resources page to help plan your special 90th anniversary meeting http://ow.ly/CPbFh.  #Toastmasters #TI90years #Whereleadersaremade.

In honor of our upcoming 90th Anniversary, chime in on our history themed  Tuesday Table Topic :
If you had the chance to meet Toastmasters' founder Dr. Ralph C. Smedley, what is one question you would ask him?  
For more table topic ideas, click here http://ow.ly/CKn1q .#Toastmasters #TI90Years #TableTopicTuesday. Toastmasters International - Toastmasters’ 90th Anniversary Resource Kit. It’s time to get excited about Toastmasters’ 90th anniversary! Get your club involved this October with a history-themed club meeting and an open house for the community. It’s also a great time to start documenting your club’s history. Tag your event photos on social media with the hashtag #TI90year….

Are you close to reaching your next #Toastmasters Educational Achievement?

All members  who achieve an education award in the month of October will receive a Limited Edition 90th Anniversary Static-Cling Decal with their certificate or plaque. You can add it to your car, home or office window to show off your Toastmasters pride. Additional decals can be purchased here: http://ow.ly/Cd8zK.
#WhereLeadersAreMade #TI90Years. Timeline Photos.

It’s that time again for some Toastmasters Trivia in honor of our upcoming 90th anniversary! 
The question is… “Who was the first president of Toastmasters International?”
Everyone that answers correctly will be entered for a chance to win a FREE Toastmasters Keychain (Item 5997)! Comment here or email socialmedia@toastmasters.org with your answer by 5 PM PST. Good luck!  #TI90Years #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

It’s time for some Toastmasters Trivia in honor of our upcoming 90th anniversary! The question is… “What date marks the official anniversary of #Toastmasters International?”
Everyone that answers correctly will be entered for a chance to win a FREE Toastmasters Keychain (Item 6994). Comment here or email socialmedia@toastmasters.org with your answer by 1 p.m. Good luck!  #TI90Years #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

Attention #Toastmasters! We have an anniversary coming up! 

On October 22nd Toastmasters International turns 90.  Help us celebrate by sharing FREE anniversary resources with your club: http://ow.ly/BkAXZ #TI90years #breakingtheicesince1924 #WhereLeadersAreMade. Timeline Photos.

Forbes Dr Nick Morgan talks with Dan Rex, CEO of Toastmasters International about ‘Why You Should Join #Toastmasters ’ 
http://ow.ly/YtV9Z 

#PublicSpeaking #Communications #Leadership #YMCA #Speakers #WhereLeadersAreMade. Why You Should Join Toastmasters. Toastmasters offers everyone a chance to practice public speaking.

Why Join #Toastmasters?
"I've become convinced that a person's impact on the world is much greater when he or she is a good communicator and leader"- Brett Hoffstadt, ACB http://ow.ly/Uqx29. Timeline Photos.

Why join #Toastmasters?
As a small-business owner, Edward Wedler, says Toastmasters taught him to listen, and be tolerant and patient http://ow.ly/PEbIp #communication. Timeline Photos.

Why join #Toastmasters?

Stacey Shipman, ACS, ALS joined #Toastmasters to shift careers and launch a public speaking and media business.  Her new career as a speaker has allowed her to bring her communication skills and interests in yoga together in her work.  Read her story here: http://ow.ly/LxRHC #publicspeaking #meditation. Why did you join #Toastmasters?

Neil Coleman, CL, joined after an email urged him to "take courage."  Learn how Toastmasters has helped him become a better communicator and gain confidence here: http://ow.ly/KvxKE. Timeline Photos.

Is your club using the new Toastmasters International
 mobile app? Send us a one- to two-minute video and show how the mobile app has made your club roles easier!

Video Contest Prize
If you submit the winning video to brand@toastmasters.org, you will be eligible to win $200 worth of branded materials. Videos that are selected will be posted on this page as well as other various Toastmasters social media outlets.

To Enter the Contest
To compete for the month of May, please email a link of your club’s video by May 31st, 2016.

The April 2016 Video Brand Contest Winner was the Naturally N’awlins from Kenner, LA. Congratulations!

http://bit.ly/1VmrFJO

#Toastmasters #Video #Winning #TIMobileApp. Toastmasters International -Video Contest. Is your club using the new Toastmasters International mobile app? Send us a one- to two-minute video and show how the mobile app has made your club roles easier!

#Toastmasters, Enter for your chance to #win $100 worth of branded materials. All you have to do is submit a photo of you and other members during your Toastmasters club meeting using the Toastmaster International Mobile App.

Ways to submit your photo:
1. Using Instagram, tag your photo #TIMobileAppContest
2. Email your photo to socialmedia@toastmasters.org
3. Fill out the online form on Toastmasters site http://bit.ly/TIContest_Instagram

Contest runs from Monday, May 9 and ends on Monday, May 23. Winning photo will be announced on our Toastmasters International Instagram Page on Monday, May 30 at 9 a.m. PT.

Looking for a #Toastmasters club near you? Toastmasters International has 14,650 clubs in 126 countries.  Plus, check out our  #TravelingToastmaster! Photos from Toastmasters International's post.

Want more #Toastmasters history?

Historian Paul Clark commemorates our 90th anniversary in this Toastmasters #podcast.  Listen to his interview now: http://ow.ly/FC4At #communication. Photos from Toastmasters International's post.

Toastmasters International Celebrates!
 
Today we celebrate our organization’s 90-year legacy of creating confident speakers and leaders, and our promising future as a leading global educational organization.  We are so honored to be a part of such an amazing organization! Photos from Toastmasters International's post.

Celebrate Good Times, Come On!  
It’s time to celebrate #Toastmasters 90th anniversary. Clubs around the world are celebrating with themed parties and open houses.  

Last night Smedley Chapter One Club celebrated with balloons, cake and and special guests  #Whereleadersaremade #TI90Years #TI90Reasons. Photos from Toastmasters International's post.

Darren LaCroix
Armando Cristifori
Heath Suddleson. Photos from Toastmasters International's post.

#PublicSpeaking #Communication #Podcast #Toastmasters #Speaker. Toastmasters Podcast #101: Introducing Ellie Kay, Toastmasters' Newest Accredited Speaker. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett, Ryan Levesque, and Greg Gazin.

Toastmasters Podcast #100: Mohammed Qahtani—2015 World Champion of... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett, Ryan Levesque, and Greg Gazin.

Want to know more about the 2015-2016 #Toastmasters International President? 

Learn more about Jim Kokocki in this Toastmasters podcast: http://ow.ly/U3K4x. Toastmasters Podcast #099: Introducing the 2015–2016 Toastmasters... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett, Ryan Levesque, and Greg Gazin.

Want to learn more about the #Toastmasters revitalized education program?

Hear from Deb Arrington, Ambassador from District 55, about what she's learned in the role and her thoughts about the upcoming changes in this #Toastmasters podcast: http://ow.ly/S0yaT. Toastmasters Podcast #098: Deb Arrington—Toastmasters REP Ambassador. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett, Ryan Levesque, and Greg Gazin.

This is inspiration!

Greg Gazin speaks with Peter Kossowan, DTM, in this #Toastmasters podcast.  Peter Kossowan "Mr. Toast" is a master club-builder who has chartered 164 clubs and counting. Listen to it now: http://ow.ly/M1QLH. Toastmasters Podcast #092: Peter Kossowan—Mr. Toast: A Master Club-Builder. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett, Ryan Levesque, and Greg Gazin.

Vikas Jhingran explains how to use emotions to make your message memorable in the latest #toastmasters #podcast: ow.ly/wL6FJ. Toastmasters Podcast #079: "Emote" with 2007 World Champion of Public Speaking, Vikas Jhingran. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Explore the difference between male and female communication styles in the latest #Toastmasters #podcast.  

Caren S. Neile, Ph.D., explains the gender communication gap and how being aware of it is beneficial for both men and women.  Listen now: http://ow.ly/tPMhq  #communication. Toastmasters Podcast #076: Caren S. Neile - The Gender Communication Gap. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

The Eyes Have It! 

Listen to the latest #Toastmasters podcast on communicating effectively with your eyes, featuring Ruth Nasrullah.

She shares information about eye contact and expressive body language and explains the differing #cultural attitudes regarding the issue of #eye contact.  Tune in now: http://ow.ly/sV6OP. Toastmasters Podcast #075: Ruth Nasrullah - The Eyes Have It. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

#Toastmasters International is revitalizing its #education program! 

The world is changing and we are changing with it! The new program will be one of the most significant Toastmasters projects. Listen to our latest podcast now to learn about all the exciting changes: http://ow.ly/qiJFE. Toastmasters Podcast #074: The Revitalized Education Program with Daniel... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Looking for your next speaking opportunity? It could be at your Alma Mater!

Tune in to #Toastmasters latest live podcast as expert, Jennifer Cunningham, shares her expertise on college alumni speaking opportunities. Listen now! http://ow.ly/oKAJQ. Toastmasters Podcast #072: Going Back To College as the Teacher. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Check out the latest #Toastmasters podcast! 

It features four 2013 #Toastmasters International Convention speakers, including: Sheryl Roush, Erica Dhawan, Dr. Hassan Tetteh and Judy Carter.  They offer tips and strategies related to leadership- and communication-themed topics. Listen now: http://ow.ly/mV5Xx. Toastmasters Podcast #071: 2013 International Convention Special Sneak... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Don’t miss part 2 of the #TIConv13 sneak peak podcast featuring @susancain @theRyanJenks @VincentPhipps http://ow.ly/mo1k5. Toastmasters Podcast #070: 2013 International Convention Special Sneak... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

The 2013 International Convention is only 74 days away! 

Can't wait? Check out our latest podcast from speakers Sam Davidson, Roger Love, Conor Cuneen, Ed Tate and Kent Maggard. They offer a sneak preview of the presentations they will deliver at the International Convention in August, in Cincinnati, Ohio.  Listen now! http://bit.ly/11nDqzx. Toastmasters Podcast #069: 2013 International Convention Special Sneak Preview! (Part 1) The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Need Tips on Taming Your Stage Fright?

In our latest podcast, Matt Abrahams, author of the book Speaking Up Without Freaking Out and a presenter on speaking anxiety at the 2012 International Convention, discusses how to tame your stage fright. Listen now! http://bit.ly/11i6N8D. Toastmasters Podcast #067: Matt Abrahams Offers Tips on Taming Your Stage Fright. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

How can the power of positive thinking help you?

In our latest Toastmasters podcast, Judith C. Tingley, Ph.D and Bo Bennett talk about what it means to think positively and how positive thinking can help self-improvement in public speaking as well as other areas of life.  Listen here: http://bit.ly/Z0yOO4. RSS Feed. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Listen to the new Toastmasters podcast with Susan Cain, author of the New York Times best-selling book "Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking," 
Are you an introvert or an extrovert? Listen to the Toastmasters Podcast #064: Susan Cain, The Power In Being Who You Are. Susan discusses how introverts can overcome their fear of public speaking and become powerful leaders and communicators.
 
Susan Cain is a former Toastmaster and popular speaker at the TED2012 conference and is also profiled in the December issue of Toastmaster Magazine.

http://bit.ly/10UIO10. Toastmasters Podcast #064: Susan Cain, The Power In Being Who You Are. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

While visiting Toastmasters around the world, International President John Lau, DTM, stopped into the Toastmasters' Podcast studio! 

Listen to him speak with Bo and Ryan about leadership, his time in Toastmasters and goals for his presidential term! http://bit.ly/WHJtln. Toastmasters Podcast: Meet John Lau, DTM, 2012 Toastmasters... The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Live interviews from an elevator at the 2012 Toastmasters International Convention! 
Listen to the new Toastmasters International podcast live from the Hilton Orlando Bonnet Creek Resort elevator at the 2012 Toastmasters International Convention. Fellow Toastmasters provide impromtu elevator speeches when asked "What's the one piece of advice you would give your fellow Toastmasters on communication and/or leadership?" http://bit.ly/TIConvpodcast3. Toastmasters Podcast #059: 2012 International Convention Special Sneak Preview! (Part 3) The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Hear speakers from the International Convention on the Toastmasters podcast!
Listen to tips and strategies from the International Convention speakers. Speech and voice coach Paddy Kennedy,  Henry Givray; entrepreneur and consultant, Lars Sudmann and 2011 World Champion of Public Speaking Jock Elliott offer a sneak preview of the education sessions each will present at the International Convention. http://bit.ly/conventionpodcast2. Toastmasters Podcast #058: 2012 International Convention Special Sneak Preview! (Part 2) The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

Toastmaster Croix Sather ran 100 marathons and gave 100 speeches within 100 consecutive days. More: http://bit.ly/xkavfp via @theTMpodcast. Toastmasters Podcast #054:  Speaking on the Run. The official podcast for Toastmasters International, hosted by Bo Bennett and Ryan Levesque.

clusters.summary: One day I mustered the courage to ask him, “Sir, how can I improve my speaking skills?” In response he simply said, “Join Toastmasters.” That’s when the magic of Toastmasters began in my life. He also listed it as a goal in my evaluation: Join an organization such as Toastmasters, get better at public speaking and give several presentations to groups—all by the time of the next evaluation. When I joined Toastmasters I was astonished by all of the support and opportunities made available to me by fellow Toastmasters and my confidence grew rapidly. Within that time, I served as vice president education for two clubs, a club mentor, host of the First Timer Contest at the Toastmasters 2016 Spring Conference in Windsor, Canada, and I am currently fulfilling my role as director for Area 19 Division D, as a part of my journey to Distinguished Toastmaster status. My experience and training from Toastmasters has helped me to advance my career and I am now the corporate training manager for one of the largest optical companies in the country.
messages:
Portrait of a Toastmaster, Valsakumar P. Menon, DTM
Dubai Toastmasters Club, Dubai, United Arab Emirates

I Achieved My Secret Dream

In 2002, I was 35 years old and doing well professionally as a senior manager with a reputed organization in Dubai. But I faced a big challenge: I could not muster the courage to speak to a group of people. When it came to one-on-one conversations or speaking to a group of friends, I had no issue. But put me in front of three people I didn’t know and I would become tongue-tied, forgetting everything I had prepared. 
But I was in awe of people who could do that. So I nurtured this secret dream to
be a speaker and trainer—a dream I thought would never come true. 
In those days, a gentleman would occasionally come to our organization and deliver coaching and education sessions. One day I mustered the courage to ask him, “Sir, how can I improve my speaking skills?” In response he simply said, “Join Toastmasters.” That’s when the magic of Toastmasters began in my life.
I have been a member of the Dubai Toastmasters club for the last 14 years, and my life has completely changed. Going from someone who couldn’t utter two words in front of an audience to someone who speaks for a living, I have realized my dream of being a speaker, trainer and entrepreneur.
My journey was not easy at first. But the encouragement, support and motivation I drew from club members helped me come to terms with my fear. I could never thank Ralph C. Smedley enough for creating Toastmasters. I do my bit to promote Toastmasters within the community so that more people can benefit from its magic. We also bring the program to children through our Gavel clubs and Youth Leadership programs. 
Toastmasters has given me so much. I am better-equipped to cope with life’s ups and downs. In short, the program has helped to bring out a better version of me and I am eternally grateful.
 
#Toastmasters #DubaiToastmastersClub #publicspeaking #Wednesdaywisdom #leadership #career #speech #Youthleadershipprograms #RalphcSmedley #Dubai #PortraitofaToastmaster. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster, Michael Sloan, CC, CL
Talking Point at Docklands, Victoria, Australia 

How Toastmasters Made Me a Great Dad

From sleepless nights to constant diaper changes, caring for babies comes with a host of new challenges, but unlike Toastmasters, there are no manuals to follow. I have benefited from Toastmasters in my professional development, but as an unexpected bonus, it also made me a great dad! 
When I’m with my baby daughter Zoe, all of my Toastmasters skills are on full display. My Table Topics training comes out when she points at a random object and expects an on-the-spot explanation of what it is. My vocal variety oscillates between highs and lows as I bring characters like Miss Piggy and Hippo to life before my daughter’s eyes. And anything within her grasp becomes a visual aid with which I can teach, entertain or distract her. There is never a dull moment and I get the same joy and adrenaline rush in the day-to-day moments with my daughter as I get from an invigorating Toastmasters meeting. The only difference is that my energy needs to last much longer when I’m with Zoe.  
My daughter has also taught me how to be a better Toastmaster. My speaking has improved as I incorporate more emotion into my talks and I am better attuned to listening and observing things because of her. I’ve collected amusing anecdotes, pondered life changing decisions and made lifestyle adjustments—all great material for new speeches.
In parenting there are no ribbons, awards or rounds of applause when you complete a task, but it is such a rewarding experience, full of laughs and tender moments. So thank you Toastmasters for teaching me not only speaking and leadership skills, but for also providing me with a loose parenting manual. And thank you Zoe for teaching me what life is all about.  

#Toastmasters #portraitofatoastmaster @talkingpointtm #parenting #publicspeaking #career #speech #leadership. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster, A St. Patrick’s Day Proposal

Peter Junker, ACB, Atlas ‘Olelo Hui, Honolulu, Hawaii

It was a memorable St. Patrick's Day last year for those who attended the Atlas ‘Olelo Hui Toastmasters meeting. I delivered my first speech from the Professional Speaker manual. It was entitled “You're Never Too Old.” 

I listed all the things that I was not too old to start. I shared how I became a stand-up comedian at age 52, a photographer at 55, and a Toastmaster's competitor and second place district winner at 62.  

I went on to describe how I fell in love at the age of 64, and showed photos of my sweetheart, Monica, that I thought showed off her personality. I had invited Monica to attend the meeting that day, so after sharing the pictures I asked her up to the lectern to formally introduce her to my Toastmasters friends and vice versa. After the introductions, I calmly asked Monica to marry me. After a nervous giggle, she said "Yes!"  

I then remarked that “the greatest lesson I have learned is that you're never too old to get married as I will be 66 when we exchange vows.”

Later Monica evaluated my speech and used the sandwich method.  She said I did a great job of capturing the audience's interest, the speech was well organized and the content was enjoyable. One area she thought could have been better was if I told her I loved her, but overall, she thoroughly enjoyed the speech and was glad she got to hear it in person and be a part of it. I now plan on incorporating what I learned from her evaluation as I work on our wedding vows.

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmaster #stpatricksday2017 #ToastmastersDistrict49 #Proposal #PublicSpeaking #AtlasOleloHuiToastmasters. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster, Allan G. Bluman, ACG
McKeesport Area club, White Oak, Pennsylvania 

A Lecture and a Speech 

As a mathematics teacher of 39 years at the high school, college and graduate school levels, I know how to give a lecture. But when I joined Toastmasters in 1972, the first thing I learned was there is a difference between giving a lecture and a speech.  

One of the most important things Toastmasters taught me was how to deliver an acceptance speech. In 2010 I was inducted into the McKeesport High School Alumni Hall of Fame and was required to give a short speech at the award ceremony. Fortunately for me, the Special Occasion Speeches manual has a five-to-seven minute speech entitled “Accepting an Award.”

The manual stated there are three main ingredients for this type of speech: gratitude, recognition and sincerity. For the gratitude part, I acknowledged my wife and my father, who both played a major role in my achievements. For the recognition part, I thanked the Alumni Hall of Fame committee for recognizing my achievements. For the sincerity part, I expressed my appreciation for the reward. 

The manual also included some information on minding my manners and receiving the award. All this in five to seven minutes! I was able to practice my speech in front of the McKeesport Area club, and I received evaluation tips on what to improve. One of my fellow Toastmasters even gave me some tips on how to refrain from crying during the speech.

Needless to say, when the time came for me to give my speech in front of 250 people, all went well. Thank you, Toastmasters International!

Portrait of a Toastmaster, Stefanie Chow, DTM
Rhino Business club, San Francisco, California

Speaking Up for Meaningful Causes
For the first 16 years of my life, I was painfully shy – never standing up for myself or what I believed in. I allowed myself to be teased in school, and never asked questions in class or in life. Even when I started actively volunteering in my community, I couldn’t fully express why I cared so much about these causes or convince others to care. Things changed when I joined  Toastmasters in August 2013. My confidence grew, my stage presence became more powerful, and my storytelling skills were sharpened.  
The rewards of this transformation became clear when I got involved with an organization called Freedom House, which runs shelters for human trafficking survivors in the Bay Area. In April 2016, I was asked to teach a class on human trafficking at the UC Berkeley.
I accepted the challenge. Three years prior, I would have been consumed by my insecurities as a speaker and unable to make an impact. These students were there to learn, and I had important facts and stories to share with them. I could feel their growing passion with every question asked and every life experience shared. At the end of class, the organizers told me I was the most engaging presenter of that lecture series. 
By improving communication and leadership skills, Toastmasters helps people deepen relationships, enhance presentations, and become an overall better version of themselves. Because of Toastmasters, I can speak up for myself and the causes I care about. This is why I choose to give back as the club growth director of District 4, where I’m tasked to build new clubs and strengthen existing ones. I’m passionate about creating an environment so more Toastmasters can learn how to be more effective in the areas of their lives that matter to them the most.

Portrait of a #Toastmaster: Joanne Fox, CC
Toastmasters’ Canton Public Speaking club, Canton, Ohio 

Toastmasters has been a vital part of my life for 64 years, although I didn’t initially recognize it as such.  
I was only 2 years old when my father, William Hewett, joined what was formerly known as the American Legion Toastmasters club in Canton, Ohio, in 1952. That was the beginning of his 60-year tenure as a Toastmaster, and the start of my childhood memories as well. I remember the club’s Christmas parties with Santa, and summer picnics with ball games. I remember my father rehearsing his speeches in our living room, as I often wondered, What’s that all about? 
My father became a fine speaker over the next few decades and enjoyed the research necessary to give his various speeches. Then in 1974, a young man by the name of Dennis Fox joined my father at his club. One year I was asked to provide piano carol music for a Christmas party hosted by the club, and since my parents were in Florida that year, they asked Dennis to escort me to and from the party. We began dating and got married a year and a half later. 
Although the American Legion Toastmasters club was exclusively for men at the time, guests and wives were invited to attend the speech contests. While giving moral support to Dennis, I began to see how speeches were given in front of an audience. However, I didn’t discover the full scope of Toastmasters until I joined in 2012—by that time, the club (now called Toastmasters’ Canton Public Speaking club) had changed its all-male policy.  
I joined because I am passionate about our food system and have grave concerns about how the animals we eat are treated and how crops are grown. I wanted to have a reason to dig deeper and give voice to my beliefs and concerns. However, I have gained much more than I anticipated. I have not only learned how to prepare a speech and deliver it well, but also how to listen and evaluate others. 
Toastmasters is a significant part of my life. With my father’s 60 years as a member, my husband’s 42 years and my own four-year involvement, Toastmasters has always been a family affair.

Portrait of a Toastmaster, Earlena Brown, DTM
Tube Masters, Orangeburg, South Carolina

How I Earned My DTM in Two Years
When I first joined Toastmasters, I was very interested in how long it took members to earn the Distinguished Toastmaster award. I met members who received it in five years and those who took over 10 years to earn it. At 53 years of age, I didn't want to take that long to earn this prestigious honor.  After some research online, I found that the shortest amount of time on record was two years and one day, and developed a plan to earn my own DTM in two years (strategically knocking off the one day).
 
I “studied” Toastmasters as if it was a Masters level course. I joined a total of five clubs, held several offices at the club and district level, and solicited the help of several DTMs and past district governors to teach me all that I needed to know to became a Toastmaster Guru!  I was strategic with every speech, every project, and nothing I did in the name of Toastmasters went undocumented. 

I was awarded my DTM at the 2015 District 58 Fall Conference, and held a breakout session entitled, "Work Smarter, Not Harder - Road to DTM in Two Years". I shared my strategy with the group and it was well received by all. I've had several of the session attendees approach me over the last several months to thank me for the tips and tools from the session.

Being a DTM is such a wonderful honor. It takes a lot of work, but it is an indication of the improvements I've made in my leadership and communication skills. I've helped other people grow and develop as well.  I think every Toastmaster can use some tips on how to strategically work Toastmasters into their daily routine and receive a DTM in their shortest amount of time.

I began my Toastmasters journey in September 2013, after a year of receiving non-stop invitations to attend meetings. Up until that point I had resisted going because of my busy school schedule, which kept me occupied four evenings out of the week. 

I was invited to E.T. Communicators Toastmasters Club, which met every Friday evening. This meant becoming a Toastmaster would have me involved in an activity every evening of the week. But after experiencing the Toastmasters educational program, I felt it could improve my writing and speaking skills and I became a member of the club on October 1, 2013.  

Upon joining, I enthusiastically engaged with the challenging projects in my Competent Communication manual. Each project moved me up the communication ladder one at a time. I soon became a more confident and willing participant in my weekly Bible study group discussions. 

By the time I completed my eighth project in the CC manual, it was time for office elections for the 2014-2015 term. I was elected vice president education that year, and as president for the 2015-2016 term. These demanding roles caused me to develop faster than I would have otherwise. They developed my self-confidence and leadership skills, which were noticed by many people. 

Nothing is more frustrating than to have a great idea that you are excited about, but are unable to communicate your thoughts in a manner that grabs the attention of the people you want to influence.  Lee Iacocca once said, "You can have brilliant ideas, but if you can't get them across, your ideas won't get you anywhere." To become proficient at anything requires practice. 

Through practice and feedback, Toastmasters affords you the opportunity to develop your speaking voice and leadership skills.

The Power of a Speech Contest

My most powerful Toastmasters experience was competing in the International Speech competition in 2015. The competition began on the anniversary of my fifth year of being a member of Toastmasters International. I'd had the pleasure of serving as a club officer for my entire membership at that point and had served as an area governor the prior fiscal year. I'd mentored members and a club, but the competition far surpassed my expectations. 

At the time, I served as a literacy tutor/mentor in an elementary school in Washington, D.C. Prior to that, I tutored an adult student. Drawing on those experiences, I used this competition to highlight illiteracy among youth and adults. As a member of two Toastmasters clubs, I received positive feedback and encouragement to work harder. Additionally, I was able to practice at the elementary school where I served with supportive feedback from the staff.
 
At the area and division levels, the competition was stiff, but the contests were enjoyable. To my surprise, my fellow district level competitors were encouraging. Though I'd not met most of them prior to that event, they helped me have a positive experience. The confident members shared with the less confident members. The audience was very engaging. They laughed and sighed just as if I had cued them in. 

Though I did not progress past the district level, I gained another level of confidence and humility. The experience gave me the desire to continue working in my community. The feedback from viewers let me know the topic touched many members. After the competition, some shared of a parent who stepped from the shadows of illiteracy or that of a young person they knew who struggled at one time. As a result of my experience, I recommend all members compete in a speech contest.

Aileen Aiker Tan, DTM,Singapore Institute of Management Toastmasters, Bras Basah, Singapore

The Epitome of Communication Success

My Toastmasters’ journey started more than 25 years ago at a moment of despair over my own inability to articulate my ideas at work. Looking back, I am proud to have made that critical decision to develop my communication and leadership skills, despite being a working mother, student and wife.  

I joined the Singapore Institute of Management Toastmasters Chapter II with no idea of what to expect. After my Ice Breaker, I was told that our club was facing a membership crunch and I was brought into the executive committee as vice president membership, followed by vice president education and then club president in 1994 and again in 2012. I also held district officer positions as area and division governor and helped set up new clubs over the years. 

These unique opportunities taught me invaluable lessons on interpersonal communication and crisis management. Indeed, life is about managing our challenges. The obstacles we face may be overwhelming at times, but everything is possible if we chose to see things from a fresh perspective. Whether it is an objection or a rejection, a different viewpoint can make all the difference. We cannot insulate ourselves from the current climate of increasing globalization and competition, but the ability to negotiate and create a win-win situation is the epitome of communication success. 

One of the everlasting gems I have learned from Toastmasters is to have an open mind to the fresh ideas presented by members at each meeting. Such unique exposure enriches the mind and helps us solve challenges with creative solutions. 

Having devoted a large part of my life to Toastmasters and continuous learning, I am very proud to have achieved success in my career and the ability to become financially independent.  Thank you Toastmasters for such a unique experience!

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Gary Shedd and Jack O’Malley, ATMG
Community Toastmasters Club
Muskegon, Michigan 

Half-Century Toastmasters

Community Toastmasters Club in Muskegon, Michigan, was chartered May 1, 1965. Fifty-one years is a long time for a club to remain active, but even more fascinating is that two men, Jack O'Malley and Gary Shedd, have belonged to that club for 50 years!
Back in l966, Gary was new in his real estate practice and felt awkward and self-conscious as he worked with clients. His boss suggested Toastmasters as a way to help him relax and enjoy building client relationships. He joined and now credits Table Topics for teaching him how to think on his feet and talk to anyone about anything.

“Toastmasters helped me learn to listen to someone give a speech and not think about other things or myself,” Gary says. “It carried over into my career, because I really have to listen to what my clients are saying so I can help them. And it’s not just listening skills that I learned, it’s also about being aware of their body language, vocal inflections and eye contact.”

Jack also joined the club in 1966. He was selling office products at the time, and like his friend Gary, he joined because his boss recommended it. Jack says, “I was scared to death of speaking in public, but everyone in the club was so helpful.” He almost quit several times, but the friendliness of the other members kept him coming back. He said women were not allowed in the club at first; however, once they did join, the club grew stronger.

The skills Jack learned in Toastmasters are invaluable to him. “I didn’t pursue a lot of formal education when I was young, but Toastmasters has given me a ‘Ph.D.’ in speaking, listening and communicating,” he says. “I am proud to be a 50-year Toastmaster, and I hope I have helped as many people over the years as have helped me.”

Contributed by Sue Mills, ACS, ALB, Top O' The Rock Toastmasters club, Jacksonville, Florida.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:

David E. Elston, DTM, C Division Advanced Speakers 5799, Grand Ledge, Michigan

Climbing the Corporate Ladder

Back in 2012, I was having my yearly performance review with my boss, who at that time was Chief Financial Officer (CFO) of Memorial Healthcare in Owosso, Michigan. During my review, he asked me what I wanted to be doing in five years. I told him I wanted his job.

I am director of finance, which is one step below the CFO position. My boss told me I needed to learn the skills of public speaking, because CFOs give presentations to boards, finance committees, employee groups and community groups. He also listed it as a goal in my evaluation: Join an organization such as Toastmasters, get better at public speaking and give several presentations to groups—all by the time of the next evaluation. I waited almost a year before I acted.

Once I started Toastmasters, I was hooked. I joined a few clubs and tried to speak as often as possible. Many of my speeches were about my life—my family, friends and experiences. I constantly strove to improve my skills, and it worked: I earned my DTM in
22 months. And I am currently working on my second.

I was 56 when I joined Toastmasters so I felt that I needed to master public speaking quickly to help my chances of job advancement. I now know how to prepare speeches and deliver them well. I gained confidence that I never had before. Toastmasters has made a large improvement in my professional and personal life.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Sojan Paul, ACB, ALB
Alturki Toastmasters Club
Al Kohbar, Saudi Arabia

Why Did I Join Toastmasters?

Why join Toastmasters? 
I’ve been asked this question repeatedly since I joined my club. The answer is simple; I wanted to be a better communicator. All living beings are communicators, either directly or indirectly. A blossoming flower has something to communicate to its pollinators. An ant has even more to communicate with its coworkers and competitors. If we listen, the message is clear. But we often do not listen. 
When I attended my first club meeting, the Table Topicsmaster called me onstage. That was, in fact, the first time I faced an audience. I went to the stage, looked at the audience and felt them staring at me as if I were a rare animal. To make a long story short, I couldn’t utter a single word that day. 
After that, I asked myself, why should I go again? The answer came immediately. The worst had already happened, and there was no need to be afraid any longer. If I could utter a single word this time, it would be a great achievement. I did attend the second meeting, and I haven’t stopped attending since. The more meetings I attend, the less afraid I am on stage.
So far I have won 14 trophies in club- and area-level speech contests. I also participated in a division-level contest and won in all five categories, including Table Topics! I could do this only because of #Toastmasters. My goal is to become the World Champion of Public Speaking® .

Toastmasters International
#PortraitofaToastmaster #PublicSpeaking #Communication #WhereLeadersAreMade #AlturkiToastmastersClub #SaudiArabia. Timeline Photos.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Mark Ma, CC, HKIE Toastmasters Club, Hong Kong, China

Learning the Language

 I was a “poor language” man who was good at mathematics. I hardly passed the languages part of the entrance exam at the University of Hong Kong. In fact, I failed the oral part of the exam, both in English and in Chinese (my first language). However, my life started to change after I joined Toastmasters seven years ago.

I can feel my gradual improvement in various aspects of English. I went from being too shy to speak to daring to speak and being willing to listen. I participated in speech contests and even won first place in my home club. Last year, I was fortunate to serve as club president and learned a lot, especially about listening. I went from not reading to liking to read and write. I regularly read the Toastmaster magazine from which I learn vocabulary while being inspired by excellent ideas. I even enjoyed writing and submitting this article to share my story.

I love how Toastmasters helps me develop habits in speaking, listening, reading and writing. I also love the supportive learning environment which builds genuine friendships.

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmaster #ToastmasterMagazine #Education #HKIToastmastersClub #HongKong #China. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Aurora Quezada Ortega, DTM
Ixtaccihuatl Club
Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico

I Am A Winner!

In June 2008, my oldest daughter passed away at age 53 due to an aggressive cancer, leaving me without the slightest idea of how to continue with my life. I was in a deep depression and I could not accept reality. 

A dear friend told me, “Why don’t you come to a Toastmasters meeting? It might help you move on.” 

In April 2009 I attended a meeting. I already knew something about it, since my friend had talked about it several times before. I joined the Ixtaccihuatl club. In May of that year I was elected vice president education, but my problems continued. I studied and studied, but I did not understand anything. 

But thanks to my mentors, I moved forward, giving 10 speeches and earning a Competent Communicator award. After I was elected club president, I discovered abilities I had kept stored in the memory of days past—memories of my childhood and what I had inherited from my parents. From my father I learned to be a leader and to have a clear, objective goal. From my mother I learned responsibility, dignity, integrity and reciting. 

I went on to win Humorous Speech contests in 2009 and 2010, and in March 2013, I won first place in a women’s speech contest at an International Women’s Day event.

I found the most success in leadership and in educational advances in 2014 and 2015. I served as area governor and I was the club mentor for the Redjal club and a coach for the Aztlan club, both in Guadalajara. I also conducted a High Performance Leadership project, founding the Amor por Mexico Gavel club.

I am a different woman today. My self-confidence has improved and I feel valued by my Toastmasters partners, friends and family. I just turned 81, and during my six years of service I stand firm with my goals and in my motto: Serve to live and live to serve. I am a winner!

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmaster #IxtaccihuatlClub #PublicSpeaking #Family #Leadership #Integrity #InternationalWomensDay. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster

Lois Strachan - Speaker, DTM
Cape Communicators Club
Cape Town, South Africa

Don’t Tell Me I Can’t

Lois Strachan is no ordinary lady—she’s fierce in her determination to do the things others tell her she cannot do. Lois is a past District 74 Governor and an ambassador for raising awareness of the capabilities of people living with disabilities. Author of the children’s book series The Adventures of Missy Mouse, Lois is a professional speaker and storyteller and more notably, the recipient of the Tributes Excellence Awards in the literature and education category.
And to think … Lois has achieved all this and more without her sight.
Lois’ story is a remarkable one. She went blind in 1992 at age 21, after being diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. She says of that day, “The initial feeling in that hospital room was anger. I wanted to throw something and hear it shatter into a million pieces because that’s what I felt had been done to my life.”
Both of her parents were Toastmasters, but it wasn’t until 2000, at age 29, that Lois decided to join a club. Her husband, Craig, DTM, joined at the same time because he felt it would benefit his career.
Lois says, “Initially I did not make the connection between Toastmasters as a social activity and as a catalyst for transforming one’s entire life—professionally and otherwise.” It was only through active participation in the program that she realized how the benefits carried over into all aspects of her life.
One wonders what’s next for this amazing lady. Besides being an inspiration to many people within Toastmasters and throughout the greater South African disabled community, she says, “I love every moment of doing the things that people try to tell me I cannot do.” Find out more about Lois’ journey at www.loisstrachan.com.

Contributed by Zoya Mabuto, CC, 2015 District 74 International Speech Contest Champion

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmaster #PublicSpeaking #Communication #Journey #WhereLeadersAreMade #disability #diabetes #WednesdayWisdom #Africa
#CapeCommunicators. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
John Kelly, ACB, ALB
Sunbelt Speakers club
Marlborough, New Zealand 

My Marathons

In June 2013 I set a challenge for myself: I would run a marathon every month for 12 months. I didn’t know if I was fit enough or whether I could recover quickly enough between each race. But I did know that I wanted to do something that challenged me mentally, physically and emotionally.

I started the challenge in July 2013 with a 46-kilometer (approximately 28 miles) run in the hills of Christchurch, New Zealand. In August I visited an Alpine Village where I ran from the village up and over a mountain pass, to a ski field, then back again. I climbed more than 1,700 meters (approximately 5,600 feet) that day and took more than seven hours to finish.

Things were looking good. I felt strong, my fitness was improving and I was starting to get some momentum.

Then, in September of that year, I had a major setback. I was struck with a bad case of gastroenteritis. I was unable to eat for several days and rapidly lost strength and fitness. However, I was determined that this would not defeat me. I used the idea of every hardship being a twist in a great speech for each of the subsequent marathons to help me mentally battle through the hard times. This mindset was especially important when I ran 86 kilometers (approximately 53 miles) in one day to check off the last two marathons of the challenge. It also provided me with an abundance of speech material and helped rekindle my passion for Toastmasters. 

For more information about my 12 months of marathons challenge, check out www.facebook.com/12marathons

#Toastmaster #Marathon #Challenge #Leadership #NewZealand #PortraitofaToastmasters #fitness. Timeline Photos.

Portrait of a Toastmaster
Ana Bradley, CC, Bethesda Community Toastmasters
Bethesda, Maryland

Great Expectations

Can she talk? Those three words formed a question posed by an ill-informed, ignorant stranger. Ana, to whom the question was directed, delicately described that experience in response to a Table Topics question she answered during a meeting of the Bethesda Community Toastmasters. She explained how the question infuriated her, and how her mother, who was also present, was shocked.

Ana was born with Down syndrome, and while she may struggle with developmental delays and disabilities, no one in our club would ask that question. Not only can she talk, she can deliver speeches, make us laugh and command the attention of a large audience. And, she can serve as sergeant at arms for our club.

Delightful, engaging and bold are the words that come to mind when describing Ana. In one of her speeches (my favorite), she described the different dances she has learned throughout the years. She delivered it complete with ballet slippers, music and a full-on demonstration. She also asked us to get up and dance, and of course we did.

In addition to giving speeches, she enjoys introducing the word of the day. She works hard to ensure that the word is just tough enough that we need to think about it, while familiar enough that a couple of us can work it into our own speeches.
In October 2014, Ana, a long-term volunteer at the Smithsonian Institute in Washington, D.C., was hired by the Smithsonian Libraries, where she labels books, handles circulation and helps with the mail. She credits her club engagement and devoted parents with making this dream a reality.

Ana’s parents—the long-standing Toastmasters Ginny Colten-Bradley, CTM, and Michael Bradley, ACS—are the delightful staples of our club. In March 2015, our club was recognized by an organization that serves individuals affected by intellectual and developmental disabilities for our ongoing support of Ana. The truth is, it’s a two-way street. Ana supports us just as much as we support her.
Not only is Ana a great speaker—she has us expecting great things of her. We eagerly await her next achievement.

Contributed by Jennifer Collins, ACB, ALB, of Bethesda Community Toastmasters.

#Toastmasters Toastmasters International Bethesda Community Toastmasters
#PortraitofaToastmaster  #PublicSpeaking #Communication #Leadership #WhereLeadersAreMade #Smithsonian. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Ashayna N. Nisbett, CC, CL
SXM Achievers Toastmasters Club, Philipsburg, Sint Maarten

First Impressions

If you think presenting to a room full of adults is nerve-wrecking, just imagine speaking in front of 50 teenagers. How would you capture and maintain the interest of the world’s largest group of critics (in my opinion)—teenagers.

I joined Toastmasters in August 2013, exactly one year prior to embarking on a new journey as a career guidance counselor at a vocational institution with special education students. Little did I know how much the completion of the Competent Communication (CC) manual would affect my career.

My first presentation to the students at this school needed to leave a positive and lasting impression. I was scheduled to speak for 45 minutes on career guidance—my area of expertise. I was warned, “I hope you have something exciting planned. This group is a difficult bunch.” I wondered if a 45-minute presentation existed in the CC manual.

I started with a clear tone of voice and noticed that all eyes were on me—this was a good sign. To conjure up images in the minds of the students, I used simple words and appropriate gestures. As I played an interesting video for them, I heard laughter and sounds of awe and excitement. I even had the attention of teachers in the audience.

Although I was not trained as a vocational/special education teacher, in Toastmasters I developed the skills I needed to fill in as a substitute in the classroom. My skills also helped me conduct school workshops and sessions as a career guidance counselor. I love what I’m doing, and thanks to Toastmasters, I am a more effective counselor, educator and leader.

#PortraitofaToastmaster #Toastmasters #Youth #PublicSpeaking #CompetentCommunication #School #Education #workshops. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster
Walt McHugh, ATMB, CL
San Pedro Toastmasters club (District ONE Toastmasters),San Pedro, California

Still Enjoying Toastmasters

In our San Pedro Toastmasters club, chartered May 1, 1938, you will find excellent speakers, even at the tender age of 91. That 91 year old is Walt McHugh, ATMB, CL, a 35-year member and this year's President's Cup Winner of our club in California.

In his early years, Walt enlisted in the Army Air Corps to become a radar technician between the ages of 18-21, and served from 1943-46. During World War II, Walt was a radar operator/mechanic on-board a Merchant Marine manned transport ship bringing back European and Asian theater combat troops.  After the war, Walt went to college to pursue a degree in mechanical engineering from Mississippi State University.

Upon graduation, he moved to California to work in the Aerospace industry.  At the onset, he worked as a stress analyst at North American Aviation, but developed a fond interest in marketing. He developed proposals for the famous Hughes Aircraft to various military development commands, including coordinating presentations to the Chief of Naval Operations at the Pentagon.

In his later years, Walt had a career in teaching, and once retired, he spent summers as an independent contractor writing several proposals and specifications for projects.
  
During his long and illustrious Toastmasters journey, he has participated in and won several speaking contests, "gathering a few trophies along the way" as he humbly puts it. We are very proud to have Walt as a member and mentor in our club and, he says, "At age 91, I'm still enjoying the Toastmasters experience."              

Contributed by Noland Flores, CC, CL

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmasters  #publicspeaking #leadership  #DistrictOneToastmasters #SanPedroToastmasters #ArmyAirCorps #WorldWarII. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Carolyn Bolz, ACB
Riverside, California
Inland Valley Closers Club

U-Turn

When I decided to attend my first Toastmasters meeting, I drove halfway there, made a U-turn, and went back home. I wasn’t worried about giving a speech. Instead, I was concerned about having to say anything at all during the meeting. 

I have dystonia, which is a neurological disorder similar to cerebral palsy. Dystonia does not affect a person’s intelligence, but it does cause many physical symptoms, including making it difficult to speak. Fortunately, at my first Toastmasters meeting, I was able to speak clearly as I introduced myself. I also did well the following week when I gave my short Ice Breaker speech. I then went on to participate in the Table Topics Contest at the area conference where I was thrilled to be named the first-place winner. 

How could someone like me, a person who often struggles to speak, win a speech contest? It’s only because of the support and encouragement I receive from Toastmasters members. I am grateful that I did not let my physical disability keep me from attending club meetings and becoming a member of this outstanding organization. 

#Toastmasters  #InlandValleyClosersToastmasters #neurologicaldisorder #support #communication #california #PortraitofaToastmaster. Timeline Photos.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Whitney Shayo, CC
Via Christi Toastmasters - Wichita
Wichita, Kansas

A Marriage Transformed

After 10 years of marriage and the birth of our third child, I wanted a divorce.
The way I viewed my husband Pesa and our marriage had suddenly changed. A case of mild postpartum depression took over. As I saw it, everything he said and did was wrong during the first several months after our baby was born. As a homeschooling mom with a newborn, I was in the house a lot, isolated. My husband, however, was working six nights a week as a nurse. My daily combination of boredom and exhaustion made a bad situation worse.
Pesa belongs to Via Christi Toastmasters of Wichita, Kansas, but I knew very little about the club. One Wednesday evening, as he was getting ready to attend his meeting, I informed Pesa that I would file for divorce the next morning. After a lot of yelling on my part, and a lot of listening and apologizing on his, he suggested that we both go to the meeting.
For the first time, I met my husband’s fellow club members and learned how their meetings were structured. They invited me to participate in Table Topics, and I managed to come out of my shell and speak for a whopping 19 seconds.
From that week on, we made every Wednesday our official date night. #Toastmasters came first, followed by dinner and then coffee at a local bookstore. Pesa is now president of the club and I currently serve as vice president membership. Serving as officers together has helped us appreciate the value of teamwork in our marriage as well. The skills acquired from Toastmasters can be applied to all areas of life.
Pesa and I now have a blog that provides encouragement for married couples, and I also provide coaching for moms who need support. Because of Toastmasters I speak with confidence, and I’m on a mission to spread cheer everywhere I go.

Toastmasters International #Wichita #Kansas #Marraige #datenight #teamwork #ThursdayMotivation. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Steven Tragash, ACB, ALB
Desert Toasters - Toastmasters Club, Palm Desert, California
 

Exercising New Skills
I joined Toastmasters in January 2014 and am a member of Desert Toasters in Palm Desert, California. As a former senior executive, I missed public speaking and leadership challenges. I joined specifically to hone my skills in delivering speeches of all kinds, and especially those that are extemporaneous.

Little did I know that a week after our District 12 Tall Tales Contest in 2014 that I would suffer the greatest challenge of my life: a stroke in the left hemisphere of my brain.

I didn’t share the experience with my Toastmasters colleagues as I progressed through my recovery. But the weekly meetings, interaction and speech preparation helped immensely in keeping me sharp and effective in my officer roles. In addition to physical therapy, my neurologist recommended that I “exercise” my brain. Consequently, I began taking piano lessons and studying German; I have never been happier! I’ve scored the trifecta with the fantastic Toastmasters experience, an introduction to the world of music and studying another language and culture.

I have been undeterred since my stroke. Toastmasters has played a great and unexpected role in my life. I only wish I had started sooner.

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmasters Toastmasters International #publicspeaking #leadership #strokevictim #California #challenges. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster:
Juliana Heng, ACS, ALB
KPMG KL Toastmasters and PJ Bilingual Toastmasters, Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia 

My Stand-Up Debut
September 15, 2015, was a memorable day for me. I debuted as a stand-up comedian at One Mic Stand, Malaysia’s original weekly stand-up comedy open mic show! A couple weeks before my debut, I was at the train ticket counter when a colorful brochure caught my attention. I flipped it over and saw ‘One Mic Stand’—such a catchy phrase. Upon closer scrutiny, I realized that the club welcomed newbies, too.

I sent an email to the team to get a slot, and I received a positive reply very quickly. I was given three precious minutes to make people laugh. I had butterflies in my stomach, as this was my first time speaking outside of Toastmasters. However, that knot in my stomach loosened when I realized that even if the audience didn’t laugh, I still had my dad and two friends there to support me.

When it was my turn, I briefly looked at my dad and friends, smiled and began to share my jokes. The audience responded well, the ice had been broken and I was enjoying the attempt to make people laugh.

I am grateful to One Mic Stand for giving me the opportunity to learn by doing. And a big thanks to Toastmasters International  for providing me a safe and supportive environment to hone my communication skills. Now I can take on a bigger stage to bring more joy to people!

#Toastmasters #PortraitofaToastmaster #PublicSpeaking #KPMGKLToastmasters #PJBilingualToastmasters #Comedy #StandUp #Bilingual. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Ashley Nemeth, ACB, Indian Head Toastmasters
Indian Head, Saskatchewan, Canada

No Longer Hiding

Before I joined Toastmasters, I was very shy around those whom I was not comfortable with—basically, anyone other than my family. I had a hard time at work and was very sensitive to anything my boss said to me. I hated going anywhere new and meeting new people.

I was always hiding a piece of me that I was embarrassed of, even though that piece was not always easy to hide. I am visually impaired. This made it awkward to meet new people because I couldn’t pick up on social cues from their facial expressions. Shortly after joining the Indian Head Toastmasters club in 2013, I did a speech on my disability. It felt so good to have somewhere to go where I could be myself and not have to hide. I set a goal to do a speech every week and make it through all 10 projects of the Competent Communication manual.

During my journey, my vision started to deteriorate even more. Within a few months I quickly went from having fuzzy vision to not being able to see anything except for bright light. This was very hard to deal with, but with the help of Toastmasters I kept giving speeches as a way to help me cope. It made a world of difference to have that safe place to tell my story and have the support of others who never judged me.

The members of the Indian Head club continue to be there for me. When I got my first guide dog in 2014, they were some of my biggest cheerleaders. They gave me the confidence to be my own advocate. I have made a few public speaking appearances, talking about blindness and guide dogs, and have started a support group for seniors new to vision loss.

Two years ago I would have struggled to tell you my name was Ashley Nemeth. Now I speak confidently and proudly wherever I am.

#PortraitofaToastmaster #PublicSpeaking #Communication #Leadership Indian Head Toastmasters #6324 #Journey #WhereLeadersAreMade #Toastmasters. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Louise Hyland, ACG, CL at Tic Talkers Toastmasters Club #2116 from Newport Beach, California

Finding My Support System
As a member since 2003, I have long since come to value my Toastmasters friends as family, but never more than this year.
 
In March 2015, I was diagnosed with advanced breast cancer that would require a rigorous chemotherapy treatment schedule, followed by surgery and radiation. What has become a favorite activity of mine is telling anyone who will listen how my Toastmasters family continues to show up for me. Every. Solitary. Day. 

My mentor who gave me a magnificent bottle of wine forbidding me to touch it until I am 100 percent cured, so we can share it. My fellow members who drive out of their way to my new home close to the hospital to take me out to lunch or visit. The member who sends me a card at least once a week. The many members who contributed to a meal fund that allows meals to be delivered to me when I am unable to cook for myself during the worst of chemo. The cards, the books, the gifts and the homemade food.

When people find out I’m a Toastmaster, they often ask me what I feel I’ve gained from my membership. It’s a challenging question to answer, because I know what they’re looking for: improved speaking skills, confidence, networking opportunities and leadership skills. But I’m always sure to finish my answer with the attribute that may be the most important. What I have gained from my membership is love. 

#Toastmasters #PortraitofAToastmaster #Lohyland
#breastcancer #PublicSpeaking #NewPort #California. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Sandra Cittadino, CC, CL and her son Joseph
Syracuse, New York
Empire Statesmen Toastmasters Club

Speaking Through Adversity

I am a widow of 13 years and have been raising my son Joseph on my own. Joseph graduated from college with a political science degree. He has Asperger’s syndrome, an autism spectrum disorder. I established a parent support group for those with autistic children, and my son started a social club for young adults with Asperger’s. I joined Toastmasters to gain better speaking skills so I could speak publicly and to my group about autism. I have gained so much from my club! 
My son is a gifted public speaker, which is rare for people with autism. He speaks on behalf of the autism community, and lends support to local senators here in Syracuse. He joined our club about six months ago and is soaring! The time we spend together is valuable. I have seen so much growth in him—not just in his speaking ability—but also in his social interactions. Since joining the club, he has learned and practiced an increasing number of social skills.
#Toastmaster #PortraitOfAToastmaster #NewYork #PublicSpeaking #Education. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Desiree Holz, Plain Speakers, East Perth, Western Australia

A Night to Remember

I joined Toastmasters in January 2015 unable to speak in front of an audience. I battled depression and anxiety for most of my life until three years ago, when an experience dramatically shifted my perspective.

After four months in Toastmasters, I received an email inviting me to attend an event about raising awareness for men’s mental health. Instead of just attending, I contacted the organizers and asked if they were looking for guest speakers to share their own journey with depression. A week later I had an interview with the event organizer, and after a coffee, she offered me a seven-to 10-minute speaking slot at the event. I presented my speech in front of 300 guests and received publicity in the Western Australia newspapers for my courage and participation.

If it wasn’t for Toastmasters I never would have had the courage to raise my hand for such a task. Toastmasters provided me with the platform to practice my speech and receive feedback before the event. I am now approaching local schools to share my experience and help give hope to young people all over Perth.

#Toastmaster #PortraitOfAToastmaster #publicspeakers #communication #leadership #InternationalWomensDay #Courage. Portrait of a Toastmaster.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Lola Gershfeld, ACS, Orange, California, Paul Revere club

The Jump

When I joined Toastmasters 12 years ago, I never thought I would speak at the National Association of Corporate Directors conference. Toastmasters provided me a practice field where I’ve gained the skills and the confidence to make the jump into the corporate world of leadership. 
During my delivery of the conference speech, I moved comfortably onstage, and used vocal variety and appropriate body language. As I continued, I remembered the importance of maintaining eye contact, so I left the stage to get closer to my audience.
Just like a fish jumping out of a small bowl of water, I would never have jumped had it not been for Toastmasters. I had to build my confidence to make that jump. You might say that members of my club were coaches from whom I’ve learned the art of speaking.

Portrait of a Toastmaster: Wayne Abbott, ACS, CL Bloomington, Illinois, State Farm Speakeasy

All Aboard!

I have had the privilege of being one of the many guides for the U.S. National Park Service and Amtrak’s Volunteer Trails and Rails program. My Trails and Rails audiences travel on select Amtrak trains between Springfield and Chicago, Illinois. When I walk the train, I interact with individuals and small groups. Participating in Table Topics has helped me to feel comfortable answering unexpected questions. During formal presentations, I use my Toastmasters skills to entertain passengers and share facts about Abraham Lincoln, geology, animals and the history of the communities we travel through. 
When I hear the train’s loud horn, I know my audience is about to arrive and I’ll get to use my Toastmasters skills again. All aboard!
